title: 107_hr2512
content: Authorization of appropriations for United States Customs Service for enhanced activities along the Southwest border. Authorization of appropriations for the United States Customs Service to enhance border investigative resources, combat drug smuggling and money laundering, process cargo efficiently, and reduce traffic waiting times on the Southwest border. Funding includes $467,320,000 for fiscal year 2002, $417,832,000 for fiscal year 2003, and additional funds as needed in subsequent years. $158,320,000 of the 2002 funds are allocated for acquisition and deployment expenses. For fiscal year 2002, $158,320,000 is allocated for acquisition and deployment of narcotics enforcement, cargo processing, and counterterrorism technology along the Southwest border. This includes funding for mobile truck gamma ray systems, high energy pallet gamma ray systems, higher energy truck x-ray upgrades, nonintrusive inspection equipment operators, technology maintenance, Industry Partnership Programs expansion, and canine kennel construction. For fiscal year 2002, funding is allocated for various technology and equipment upgrades along the Southwest border, including nonintrusive inspection technology, Industry Partnership Programs expansion, canine kennel construction, replacement of canines, automated targeting systems maintenance, x-ray vans, tool trucks, contraband detection kits, surveillance camera systems, truck license plate reader systems, and narcotics particle detectors. Funding for various surveillance and detection systems includes remote watch cameras, counterspotter systems, truck license plate readers, narcotics detectors, land border vehicle targeting systems, under vehicle inspection systems, outbound passenger facilities, work station replacements, Customs Automated Operations System lane installations, explosive vapor trace detectors, radiation detectors, and detection training. In fiscal years after 2002, $15,832,000 annually is allocated for maintaining surveillance and detection equipment, including explosive vapor trace detectors, radiation pager detectors, radiation identification devices, and detection training. The Commissioner of Customs can also use funds for new technologies. The Commissioner of Customs can use funds allocated for equipment for technologically superior equipment that achieves the same results at a lower cost or can be obtained at a lower cost than specified equipment. The Commissioner of Customs can reallocate funds for equipment specified in different paragraphs of subsection (b). $79,000,000 in fiscal year 2002 and $172,000,000 in fiscal year 2003 will be used to increase staff at the Southwest border to reduce waiting times at entry points. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, funds will be allocated for hiring additional personnel at the Southwest border to reduce waiting times at entry points and combat drug smuggling and money laundering. $230,000,000 in each fiscal year will be used for infrastructure improvements at Customs Service facilities on the Southwest Border. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, $230,000,000 will be allocated for construction, improvement, and expansion of Customs Service facilities at ports of entry on the Southwest Border. Amounts authorized for the United States Customs Service are in addition to any other appropriations authorized by law.
